messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 55 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Algorithmic Applications of Hypergraph and Partition Containers

Paper Abstract: Abstract We present a general method to convert algorithms into faster algorithms for almost-regular input instances. Informally, an almost-regular input is an input in which the maximum degree is larger than the average degree by at most a constant factor. This family of inputs vastly generalizes several families of inputs for which we commonly have improved algorithms, including bounded-degree inputs and random inputs. It also generalizes families of inputs for which we don‚Äôt usually have faster algorithms, including regular-inputs of arbitrarily high degree and very dense inputs. We apply our method to achieve breakthroughs in exact algorithms for several central NP-Complete problems including kùëòk-SAT, Graph Coloring, and Maximum Independent Set. Our main tool is the first algorithmic application of the relatively new Hypergraph Container Method (Saxton and Thomason [ST15], Balogh, Morris and Samotij [BMS15]). This recent breakthrough, which generalizes an earlier version for graphs (Kleitman and Winston [KW82], Sapozhenko [Sap01]), has been used extensively in recent years in extremal combinatorics. An important component of our work is the generalization of (hyper-)graph containers to Partition Containers.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 55 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 55"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The fine-grained complexity of multi-dimensional ordering properties",
        "The probabilistic method",
        "3-coloring in time O‚Äã(1.3289n)ùëÇsuperscript1.3289ùëõO(1.3289^{n})",
        "Fast algorithms for max independent set",
        "Set partitioning via inclusion-exclusion",
        "Independent sets in hypergraphs",
        "The method of hypergraph containers",
        "An efficient container lemma",
        "Current algorithms for detecting subgraphs of bounded treewidth are probably optimal",
        "Average-case complexity",
        "Enumerating maximal independent sets with applications to graph colouring",
        "The complexity of theorem-proving procedures",
        "new directions in cryptography ieee transactions on information theory, v. it-22, n. 6",
        "Small maximal independent sets and faster exact graph coloring",
        "A measure & conquer approach for the analysis of exact algorithms",
        "Improved exact algorithms for counting 3-and 4-colorings",
        "A faster algorithm for finding maximum independent sets in sparse graphs",
        "Expected computation time for hamiltonian path problem",
        "Breaking the PPSZ barrier for unique 3-SAT",
        "A dynamic programming approach to sequencing problems",
        "Faster kùëòk-SAT algorithms using biased-PPSZ",
        "One-way functions are essential for complexity based cryptography",
        "On the complexity of k-SAT",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "An o (2 0.304 n) algorithm for solving maximum independent set problem",
        "Reducibility among combinatorial problems",
        "A fine-grained analysis of a simple independent set algorithm",
        "Finding small satisfying assignments faster than brute force: A fine-grained perspective into boolean constraint satisfaction",
        "On the number of graphs without 4-cycles",
        "A note on the complexity of the chromatic number problem",
        "Coverings and colorings of hypergraphs",
        "Tight hardness for shortest cycles and paths in sparse graphs",
        "On cliques in graphs",
        "Solving satisfiability in less than 2nsuperscript2ùëõ2^{n} steps",
        "An improved exponential-time algorithm for k-SAT",
        "Satisfiability coding lemma",
        "Minimizing the number of states in incompletely specified sequential switching functions",
        "Faster computation of maximum independent set and parameterized vertex cover for graphs with maximum degree 3",
        "Algorithms for maximum independent sets",
        "A new approach on solving 3-satisfiability",
        "On the number of independent sets in extenders",
        "Deciding 3-colourability in less than O‚Äã(1.415n)ùëÇsuperscript1.415ùëõO(1.415^{n}) steps",
        "A probabilistic algorithm for kùëòk-SAT based on limited local search and restart",
        "Ppsz is better than you think",
        "Hypergraph containers",
        "Planar 3-colorability is polynomial complete",
        "A simple linear expected time algorithm for finding a hamilton path",
        "Elements of information theory",
        "Finding a maximum independent set",
        "On some fine-grained questions in algorithms and complexity",
        "Exact algorithms for NP-hard problems: A survey",
        "Truly subcubic min-plus product for less structured matrices, with applications",
        "A simple and fast algorithm for maximum independent set in 3-degree graphs",
        "Exact algorithms for maximum independent set",
        "Breaking the 2nsuperscript2ùëõ2^{n} barrier for 5-coloring and 6-coloring"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 55 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Algorithmic Applications of Hypergraph and Partition Containers, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
